Article Title: Oracle cofounder Larry Ellison on the biggest problem that all AI models including ChatGPT, Gemini, Grok, Llama have
Article Text:
Oracle's Larry Ellison believes the AI race is becoming a commodity due to shared internet data. He argues the future lies in leveraging private enterprise data, a move Oracle is heavily investing in with massive infrastructure plans. While competitors are also building enterprise AI, Oracle's existing database dominance could be key to its success in this next AI wave.

The real money is in private data, not public models

Oracle's massive AI infrastructure bet faces stiff competition





Oracle cofounder and CTO Larry Ellison has put his finger on what he sees as the fatal flaw in today's AI race: every major model, from ChatGPT to Gemini to Meta's Llama, is trained on essentially the same publicly available internet data. During Oracle's fiscal Q2 2026 earnings call in December, Ellison argued this shared foundation is rapidly turning cutting-edge AI into a commodity product with razor-thin differentiation."All the large language models—OpenAI, Anthropic, Meta, Google, xAI—they're all trained on the same data. It's all public data from the internet," Ellison said. "So they're all basically the same. And that's why they're becoming commoditized so quickly."Larry Ellison's solution? The next gold rush won't be building better foundational models—it'll be enabling AI to work with proprietary enterprise data while keeping it secure. He estimates this second wave of AI will prove "even larger and more valuable" than the current boom in GPUs and data centers.Oracle is betting heavily on this vision, projecting roughly $50 billion in capital expenditures for the full year, up from $35 billion estimated just three months earlier.The company argues it has a natural advantage since most high-value private data already lives in Oracle databases. Its AI Data Platform uses techniques like Retrieval-Augmented Generation to let models query private information in real time without security compromises.The company announced partnerships at Oracle AI World in October, including a 50,000-GPU supercluster with AMD MI450 chips launching in Q3 2026 and the OCI Zettascale10 supercomputer connecting hundreds of thousands of NVIDIA GPUs. By late 2025, Oracle's cloud backlog had topped $500 billion, driven mostly by AI demand.Still, Ellison's thesis faces headwinds. Synthetic data generation could reduce reliance on exclusive proprietary datasets, while rivals like Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud are racing to build similar enterprise AI capabilities. The question is whether Oracle's existing grip on enterprise databases will prove decisive—or if the AI landscape will shift before the company's massive infrastructure bets pay off.
Article Summary: Oracle's Larry Ellison believes the AI race is becoming a commodity due to shared internet data. He argues the future lies in leveraging private enterprise data, a move Oracle is heavily investing in. While competitors are also building enterprise AI, Oracle's existing database dominance could be key to its success.

Article Title: iPhone users, you may be about to get your first real look at Google-Apple partnership for your phones starting ...
Article Text:
What’s changing in Siri



Apple's AI struggles made outside help inevitable







Apple is preparing to overhaul Siri from a voice assistant into a conversational AI chatbot, marking the most dramatic change since it launched in 2011. The new Siri will run on Google's Gemini models following a partnership Apple finalized earlier this month. Now a new Bloomberg report suggests that Apple is preparing to unveil the upgraded Siri in February 2026.“Apple appears to be less than a month away from unveiling the results of this partnership. The company has been planning an announcement of the new Siri in the second half of February, when it will give demonstrations of the functionality,” reads the report.As per the report, Siri will now integrate Gemini’s advanced generative AI capabilities, enabling more natural conversations, smarter contextual responses and deeper integration with apps. This partnership could give iPhone users access to Google’s cutting-edge AI technology directly within Apple’s ecosystem, a move that signals Apple’s willingness to lean on external AI expertise rather than building everything in-house.Siri will work with both voice and text, handling tasks like content generation, file analysis, summarization, and coding help. It'll integrate with Apple's core apps—Photos, Mail, Messages, Music—and access their content to respond to requests.Apple is also developing a feature letting Siri view open windows and adjust device settings.The deal reflects Apple's rocky journey in AI. The company delayed its major Siri upgrade from spring 2025 to 2026, sidelined AI chief John Giannandrea from development, and lost key talent including foundation models head Ruoming Pang to Meta. Apple's research and development spending has hovered at just 8 per cent of revenue while competitors poured hundreds of billions into AI infrastructure.One former Apple executive summed it up to the FT: the Google deal was "a necessary byproduct of Apple's decision not to 'go big' on its AI investments like its competitors." Apple still plans to develop its own trillion-parameter model eventually. But for now, it's betting that Google can deliver what its own teams couldn't.The existing ChatGPT integration with Apple Intelligence remains intact—for now. But analysts aren't optimistic about its future. "Having two large models, given the economies of scale, wouldn't make a ton of sense for Apple," noted Gene Munster at Deepwater Asset Management.
Article Summary: New Siri will run on Google's Gemini models following a partnership Apple finalized earlier this month. Siri will work with both voice and text, handling tasks like content generation, file analysis, summarization, and coding help. Apple delayed its major Siri upgrade from spring 2025 to 2026, sidelined AI chief John Giannandrea from development.
